title: Evolution in a big city - Jason Munshi-South

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the spring water seeping out of the ground on a forested hillside in Northern Manhattan?

options.label: A
options.text: It is contaminated with heavy metals.

options.label: B
options.text: It is the only source of water in the city.

options.label: C
options.text: You can drink it out of your hands and be okay.

options.label: D
options.text: It is only available during the winter months.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the northern dusky salamanders being stuck on a single hillside and a few places in Staten Island?

options.label: A
options.text: They are an invasive species.

options.label: B
options.text: They are a native species that has adapted to the urban environment.

options.label: C
options.text: They are suffering the indignity of being stuck on this hillside.

options.label: D
options.text: They are a source of food for other animals.

multiple-choice.question: What can be determined by taking a few segments of DNA from salamanders on either side of a bridge?

options.label: A
options.text: The exact location of the salamanders.

options.label: B
options.text: The species of the salamanders.

options.label: C
options.text: Which side of the bridge the salamanders came from.

options.label: D
options.text: The age of the salamanders.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the white-footed mouse being used as a model to understand how species are adapting to urban environments?

options.label: A
options.text: It is an invasive species.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a native species that has been in the city for a long time.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a source of food for other animals.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a source of disease for other animals.

multiple-choice.question: What is the difference between the genetic makeup of city mice and country mice?

options.label: A
options.text: They have the same genetic makeup.

options.label: B
options.text: They have a few genetic differences.

options.label: C
options.text: They have many genetic differences.

options.label: D
options.text: They have no genetic differences.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of sequencing thousands of genes from city mice and comparing them to thousands of genes from country mice?

options.label: A
options.text: To understand how species are adapting to urban environments.

options.label: B
options.text: To understand how genes are changing in urban populations.

options.label: C
options.text: To understand how disease is spreading in urban populations.

options.label: D
options.text: To understand how heavy metals are affecting urban populations.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the Manhattan plot?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a map of the city.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a graph of the genetic differences between city and country mice.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a graph of the population size of city mice.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a graph of the disease rate in city mice.

multiple-choice.question: What are the genes that are most different between city and country mice?

options.label: A
options.text: Genes that encode for things like immune response to disease.

options.label: B
options.text: Genes that encode for things like metabolism.

options.label: C
options.text: Genes that encode for things like heavy-metal tolerance.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of following the lives of individual mice in the wild?

options.label: A
options.text: To understand how species are adapting to urban environments.

options.label: B
options.text: To understand how genes are changing in urban populations.

options.label: C
options.text: To understand how disease is spreading in urban populations.

options.label: D
options.text: To understand how heavy metals are affecting urban populations.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker encouraging the audience to do?

options.label: A
options.text: To become the next Charles Darwin.

options.label: B
options.text: To look at their parks in a new way.

options.label: C
options.text: To study the urban environment.

options.label: D
options.text: To become a scientist.

title: How containerization shaped the modern world - Sir Harold Evans

options.text: Bill Gates

title: The power of simple words - Terin Izil

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea of the passage?

options.label: A
options.text: The importance of using expensive words in writing.

options.label: B
options.text: The impact of audience on writing style.

options.label: C
options.text: The benefits of using thesaurus in writing.

options.label: D
options.text: The limitations of the English language.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of using simple words in writing, according to the passage?

options.label: A
options.text: To sound sophisticated and educated.

options.label: B
options.text: To convey complex ideas in a clear manner.

options.label: C
options.text: To impress the audience with vocabulary.

options.label: D
options.text: To show off one's knowledge of expensive words.

multiple-choice.question: What is the author suggesting that writers do when it comes to using expensive words?

options.label: A
options.text: Use them as much as possible to sound impressive.

options.label: B
options.text: Use them sparingly and only when necessary.

options.label: C
options.text: Avoid them altogether and use simpler words instead.

options.label: D
options.text: Use them to fill space in their writing.

multiple-choice.question: What is the author comparing the use of expensive words to?

options.label: A
options.text: A game of Scrabble.

options.label: B
options.text: A thesaurus.

options.label: C
options.text: A book of vocabulary.

options.label: D
options.text: A dictionary.

multiple-choice.question: According to the passage, what is the effect of using expensive words that are not understood by the audience?

options.label: A
options.text: It makes the writer sound more intelligent.

options.label: B
options.text: It makes the writing more engaging.

options.label: C
options.text: It renders the words worthless.

options.label: D
options.text: It has no impact on the audience.

multiple-choice.question: What is the author suggesting that writers consider when it comes to their audience?

options.label: A
options.text: Their level of education.

options.label: B
options.text: Their level of interest in the topic.

options.label: C
options.text: Their expectations of the writing style.

options.label: D
options.text: Their attention span.

multiple-choice.question: What is the author suggesting that writers do to cater to their audience?

options.label: A
options.text: Use complex vocabulary to impress them.

options.label: B
options.text: Use simple language to communicate effectively.

options.label: C
options.text: Use a variety of writing styles to keep them engaged.

options.label: D
options.text: Use a thesaurus to find the perfect words.

multiple-choice.question: According to what is the author comparing the importance of brevity in writing?

options.label: A
options.text: Variety in life.

options.label: B
options.text: Spice in life.

options.label: C
options.text: Bread in life.

options.label: D
options.text: Water in life.

multiple-choice.question: What is the author suggesting that writers do with expensive words?

options.label: A
options.text: Use them to fill space in their writing.

options.label: B
options.text: Use them to sound sophisticated and educated.

options.label: C
options.text: Save their money and use simpler words instead.

options.label: D
options.text: Use them to impress their audience.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main point of the passage about writing?

options.label: A
options.text: The importance of using expensive words.

options.label: B
options.text: The impact of audience on writing style.

options.label: C
options.text: The benefits of using a thesaurus.

options.label: D
options.text: The limitations of the English language.

title: Symbiosis: A surprising tale of species cooperation - David Gonzales

multiple-choice.question: What is a symbiosis?

options.label: A
options.text: A relationship where one species benefits and the other is harmed.

options.label: B
options.text: A partnership between two different species.

options.label: C
options.text: A process by which one species evolves to become stronger.

options.label: D
options.text: A type of animal that lives in the ocean.

options.label: A
options.text: Blue jay

options.label: B
options.text: Clark's nutcracker

options.label: C
options.text: Hummingbird

options.label: D
options.text: Robin

options.label: A
options.text: Shelter and food

options.label: B
options.text: Only food

options.label: C
options.text: Only shelter

options.label: D
options.text: Neither shelter nor food

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: They eat them immediately.

options.label: C
options.text: They leave them on the ground to rot.

options.label: D
options.text: They take them back to their nests.

options.label: A
options.text: They dig them up and eat them.

options.label: B
options.text: They leave them alone.

options.label: C
options.text: They bury them in other locations.

options.label: D
options.text: They do not interact with the cones.

options.label: A
options.text: A pouch

options.label: B
options.text: A basket

options.label: C
options.text: A pocket

options.label: D
options.text: A container

options.label: A
options.text: GPS

options.label: B
options.text: Landmarks on the landscape

options.label: C
options.text: Maps

options.label: D
options.text: Compasses

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of how Clark's nutcrackers have evolved to suit their symbiosis with whitebark pine?

options.label: A
options.text: They have developed long, tough beaks for extracting seeds from cones.

options.label: B
options.text: They have developed the ability to fly faster.

options.label: C
options.text: They have developed the ability to climb trees.

options.label: D
options.text: They have developed the ability to swim.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of how whitebark pine has evolved to suit their symbiosis with Clark's nutcrackers?

options.label: A
options.text: Their branches all sweep upwards with the cones at the very ends.

options.label: B
options.text: Their cones are smaller.

options.label: C
options.text: Their leaves are larger.

options.label: D
options.text: Their trunks are thicker.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main benefit of the symbiosis between Clark's nutcrackers and whitebark pine?

options.label: A
options.text: It allows both species to benefit and thrive.

options.label: B
options.text: It allows one species to benefit and the other to be harmed.

options.label: C
options.text: It allows one species to dominate the other.

options.label: D
options.text: It has no benefit for either species.

title: How simple ideas lead to scientific discoveries - Adam Savage

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of the conversation between Richard Feynman and his father that had a significant impact on Feynman's future in science?

options.label: A
options.text: Feynman decided to pursue a career in mathematics.

options.label: B
options.text: Feynman credits the conversation with his father as giving him a sense that the simplest questions could carry you out to the edge of human knowledge.

options.label: C
options.text: Feynman became interested in philosophy.

options.label: D
options.text: Feynman lost interest in science.

multiple-choice.question: Who was the first person to prove that the Earth is spherical?

options.label: A
options.text: Eratosthenes

options.label: B
options.text: Aristotle

options.label: C
options.text: Christopher Columbus

options.label: D
options.text: Galileo

multiple-choice.question: What was the method used by Eratosthenes to calculate the Earth's circumference?

options.label: A
options.text: He measured the distance between two cities and used it to calculate the circumference.

options.label: B
options.text: He used the angle of the sun's shadow at noon on the solstice to calculate the circumference.

options.label: C
options.text: He measured the height of a mountain and used it to calculate the circumference.

options.label: D
options.text: He used a combination of both methods.

options.label: B
options.text: Armand Fizeau

options.label: C
options.text: Eratosthenes

options.label: D
options.text: Aristotle

options.label: C

options.label: B
options.text: He calculated the speed of light to within five percent of its actual value.

options.label: C
options.text: He calculated the speed of light to within ten percent of its actual value.

options.label: D
options.text: He calculated the speed of light to within twenty percent of its actual value.

options.label: B
options.text: A spinning top

options.label: D

options.label: A
options.text: He calculated the circumference to within one percent of its actual value.

options.label: B
options.text: He calculated the circumference to within five percent of its actual value.

options.label: C
options.text: He calculated the circumference to within ten percent of its actual value.
